009package Ch04_Filters;
010
011import ij.ImagePlus;
012import ij.gui.GenericDialog;
013import ij.plugin.filter.PlugInFilter;
014import ij.process.ImageProcessor;
015import imagingbook.common.ij.DialogUtils;
016import imagingbook.core.jdoc.JavaDocHelp;
017import imagingbook.sampleimages.GeneralSampleImage;
018
019import java.util.Arrays;
020
021import static imagingbook.common.ij.IjUtils.noCurrentImage;
022
023/**
024 * <p>
025 * ImageJ plugin for a median filter of arbitrary size. An array {@code A} of type {@code int} is defined to hold the
026 * regionâ€™s pixel values for each filter position (u, v). This array is sorted by using the standard Java method
027 * {@link Arrays#sort(int[])}. The center element of the sorted vector ({@code A[n]}) is taken as the median value and
028 * stored in the original image {@code ip}. See Sec. 4.1.2 (Prog. 4.5) of [1] for additional details.
029 * </p>
030 * <p>
031 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer
032 * (2022).
033 * </p>
034 *
035 * @author WB
036 */
037public class Filter_Median implements PlugInFilter, JavaDocHelp {
038
039        /** Filter radius. */
040        public static int R = 3; // the size of the filter is (2R+1)x(2R+1)
041
042        /** Constructor, asks to open a predefined sample image if no other image is currently open. */
043        public Filter_Median() {
044                if (noCurrentImage()) {
045                        DialogUtils.askForSampleImage(GeneralSampleImage.IrishManor);
046                }
047        }
048
049        @Override
050        public int setup(String arg, ImagePlus imp) {
051                return DOES_8G;
052        }
053
054        @Override
055        public void run(ImageProcessor ip) {
056                if (!runDialog()) {
057                        return;
058                }
059
060                final int M = ip.getWidth();
061                final int N = ip.getHeight();
062                final ImageProcessor copy = ip.duplicate();
063
064                // vector to hold pixels from (2R+1)x(2R+1) neighborhood:
065                int[] A = new int[(2 * R + 1) * (2 * R + 1)];
066                
067                // index of center vector element n = 2(R^2 + R):
068                int n = 2 * (R * R + R);
069                
070                for (int u = R; u <= M - R - 2; u++) {
071                        for (int v = R; v <= N - R - 2; v++) {
072                                // fill the pixel vector A for filter position (u,v):
073                                int k = 0;
074                                for (int i = -R; i <= R; i++) {
075                                        for (int j = -R; j <= R; j++) {
076                                                A[k] = copy.get(u + i, v + j);
077                                                k++;
078                                        }
079                                }
080                                // sort vector A and take the center element A[n]:
081                                Arrays.sort(A);
082                                ip.set(u, v, A[n]);
083                        }
084                }
085        }
086
087        private boolean runDialog() {
088                GenericDialog gd = new GenericDialog(this.getClass().getSimpleName());
089                gd.addHelp(getJavaDocUrl());
090                gd.addMessage("Filter kernel size is (2r+1) x (2r+1):");
091                gd.addNumericField("Kernel radius (r > 0)", R, 0);
092
093                gd.showDialog();
094                if (gd.wasCanceled())
095                        return false;
096
097                R = (int) gd.getNextNumber();
098                return true;
099        }
100
101}
